item.title: I Hope My Outer Worlds 2 Companions Really Do Try To Kill Me
item.content:encoded:

They amounted to a fire-suppressing peanut gallery that helped you learn about and reflect on the world around you but little more. The Outer Worlds 2 will try to fix that. Valerie is a robot from the same faction. Aza is a cultist from the Glorious Dawn. Inez is a field medic from Auntieâ€™s Choice. Marisol is an assassin from the Order of the Ascendant. Finally thereâ€™s Tristan from the Protectorate who has a giant hammer. Hurt their friends or break their rules and theyâ€™ll turn on you.

This sounds neat and builds off one of the most memorable moments from the original Mass Effect in which two of your squadmates clash, resulting in an unreconcilable showdown. I donâ€™t expect The Outer Worlds 2 to rise to the same level since these confrontations donâ€™t sound like pivotal scripted moments so much as procedural consequences.

I hope we have some real friends-to-enemies journeys out there in Halcyon this time around. One of my biggest complaints with party-based RPGs is that the people youâ€™re with never seem to quite have a mind of their own outside of sassy retorts and disappointed scowls. â€œWe still wanted to make sure that the player has choiceâ€”meaningful choiceâ€”here,â€ Singh told RPGSite in another interview. â€œCompanions are completely optional. If you donâ€™t want to engage with them, you donâ€™t have to. But you can take them along and see how that changes your story. Same thing with factions, right? The factions are there.
